qas.question: What groups combine matrices with matrix multiplication?
What includes all invertible n-by-n matrices with real entries?
What term describes subgroups of the general linear group?
What matrix group portrays all possible rotations in n dimensions?
Rotation matrix groups are utilized in computer graphics with what concept?
What are matrices and matrix groups combined called?
The general linear group describes all possible what?
What is an example of a large matrix group?
What are subgroups of the special orthogonal group called?
What type of angles are made of all invertible n-by-b matrices?

context: <a0_0>Matrix groups<a0_0/> consist of matrices together with <b5_0>matrix multiplication<b5_0/>. <a1_0>The general linear group<a1_0/> GL(n, R) consists of all invertible n-by-n matrices with real entries. Its subgroups are referred to as <a2_0><b8_0>matrix groups<a2_0/> or linear groups<b8_0/>. The <b7_0>dihedral group<b7_0/> example mentioned above can be viewed as a (very small) matrix group. Another important matrix group is <a3_0>the special orthogonal group SO(n)<a3_0/>. It describes all possible <b6_0>rotations in n dimensions<b6_0/>. Via <a4_0><b9_0>Euler<b9_0/> angles<a4_0/>, rotation matrices are used in computer graphics.
